Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Models and Analyses of Industrial Laboratories: Returns, Risks, and Structural Efficiency, with Implications for Sustainability and Science Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
During the past century, industrial laboratories, as exemplified by Bell Labs, DuPont Research, IBM Research and Xerox PARC, have made lasting contributions to scientific knowledge and technological innovations, which have benefited society, our nation's economy and the lives of its citizens. Industrial laboratories are integral to a feedback loop that couples them with engineering and business practices, with the result that researchers in the laboratories benefit from streams of new questions and challenges from the field in one direction, while solutions, prototypes and products flow in the opposite direction. This environment defines use-inspired research that complements ?open science? research performed in academic institutions. While recent experience may justifiably raise doubts on the survivability of industrial research laboratories in the current highly-competitive market environment, there are also encouraging signs: laboratories that experienced major declines are now focusing on revitalizing themselves, while newer players have arrived and are pioneering new models of industrial research. It is therefore timely to take a deep and broad look at how science and innovation policies can foster an environment in which industrial laboratories will continue to produce discoveries and inventions with broad scientific value and transformative technological impact.

Intellectual Merit

This project will develop our understanding of the operation of industrial laboratories by taking an "engineering-oriented" approach that employs analytical models and quantitative methods to systematically dissect and analyze the essential features of operation, financing, and growth of industrial laboratories and draw conclusions by carrying out logic experiments that vary policy inputs and examine their impact. In particular, the research will concentrate on three areas: 1) develop and solve an optimization problem to determine the theoretical rate of return of the investment in industrial research that can be used to identify principles for optimizing laboratory management and make conditional assessments regarding the viability of the laboratories; 2) analyze the investment risk of financing industrial laboratories, study the interaction between investment and operational decisions, and identify investment strategies that provide much-needed long-term stability for laboratories to engage in fundamental research; and 3) determine how laboratory management structure affects incentive, scale of operations, and research outputs by conducting comparative studies between the traditional integrated sequential structure and newly emerging structures of industrial research management.

Broader Impacts
The project will provide new insights that will help industrial laboratories to improve and re-invent themselves by creating the tools laboratory managers require to adopt better organizational structures, manage the financial risk of investing in the laboratory, and maximize the rate of return. The project will inform policymakers about the impact of Science policy, and other types of policy, e.g., financial regulation, on laboratory investments and operations. Finally, while the analysis is carried out at the level of laboratories, the insights and results from comparisons between the traditional vertically-integrated structure and newly emerging structures will carry-over from industrial laboratories to the discussion on the national innovation ecosystem, especially in relation to the trade-offs in coordination cost, focus of incentives, ability to conduct fundamental research, and investment mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Corporations conduct the bulk of their R&D in industrial laboratories.  Unlike universities and government laboratories, which mainly pursue “open science’’, industrial laboratories are tasked to create new profit opportunities for their parent companies. Despite this narrow focus, over many years and decades, industrial laboratories have produced a vast number of scientific and technological innovations that have led to tremendous improvements to the welfare of society. The recent decline in the scope and scale of several prominent laboratories, especially in their commitments to basic research, is evidence that the effective functioning of industrial laboratories is not automatic, and happens only in a suitable business and policy environment. Fostering such an environment requires a systematic analyses of laboratories’ incentives, processes, and decisions. The project is motivated and challenged by this need.

The project develops multiple mathematical models, which are analyzed and simulated in order to capture essential features of industrial laboratories. These models serve as platforms for conducting ``logic experiments’’ on laboratories’ management. Results are obtained for numerous scenarios, which are designed to lead to characterizations of profit-maximizing management policies and novel insights. Numerical case studies and simulations are carried out for broad ranges of input values to assess implications of changing technological and business environments.

For instance, the project takes note of a well-documented fact that investment in basic research as a share of industrial R&D spending has been steadily declining in the USA over the past few decades. To address this concerning trend, it is necessary to understand forces that may have been driving it. The project approaches this problem by considering intellectual asset production in a prototypical industrial laboratory. The analysis is based on the perspective of laboratory managers, who allocate the budgeted funds to various units, which include a research stage, where breakthrough innovations are conceived and codified, and multiple development stages, where the raw concepts and prototypes are filtered and transformed into profitable products and services.  By analyzing profit-maximizing policies of budget allocation and project management, the project identifies three possible pathways that can lead to a reduction in the amount of spending allocated to research: lack of variability in potential profits of new innovations; improvements in cost efficiency in the development units; and rapid realization of product values at early stages of development.

The project not only yields new understanding of macro trends, but also sheds insights on policies for improving managerial efficiency of the laboratory. For instance, an analysis of the aforementioned laboratory model proves that the laboratory’s profit can be maximized by investing heavily in generating new projects, rigorously evaluating them and dropping those with lower values (even when they are profitable), and concentrating resources on developing the exceptional ones. The conclusion bears some resemblance to the start-up approach casually referred to as ``fail fast and try again’’. The analysis here formalizes the strategy, sets boundaries for its applicability, and proves its optimality under given conditions.

The processes sustaining Knowledge Stock, and its impact are recurring themes of the project. Knowledge Stock represents accumulated knowledge and know-how from practicing research and development activities, and from applications of R&D, and it has traditionally been leveraged to improve productivity. While Knowledge Stock has been studied in the literature in the context of national economies, the focus in the project is on its role in corporations of the private sector. In this context there is an important fact: knowledge is subject to loss with time due to obsolescence, replacement by newer and better innovations, and even every day events, such as the retirement of key personnel. On the other hand, knowledge can be replenished, typically by the dedicated efforts of specialists, which of course requires investments. The project studies dynamic control models that explicitly capture both effects. Various strategies for investing, managing and leveraging Knowledge Stock are developed and compared through dynamic models. Results show that purely myopic profit maximization policies often lead the system to an inefficient steady-state. However, such entrapment can be avoided with a straightforward incorporation of long-term profit considerations in the control strategy, which sometimes coincide with immediate profit maximization.

The role of patent creation is a major activity in industrial laboratories and is a particular focus of the project. Data from the US Patent Office combined with publicly available data on investments in R&D by corporations in select high-tech industries have been analyzed to infer correlations.

Findings of this project have been presented at several academic conferences, especially those in engineering and operations research, and have been published in an academic journal. Major insights have been shared with managers of industrial laboratories.  The project has also served the purpose of educating and training graduate students. Several graduate students participated in data collection, modeling, analysis and simulations in the course of the project.
